abstract.p: Ajzen, Icek. 2012. Martin Fishbein’s legacy: The reasoned action approach. The Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science 640 (1): 11–27. doi:10.1177/0002716211423363

body.p:
In an article that appeared in volume 640 (Ajzen 2012), incorrect percentage differences were described in relation to a study by Brubaker and Fowler (1990) that was designed to encourage testicular self-examination (TSE) among high school students. The correct percentages should be 44 percent in the theory-based intervention condition compared to 37 percent in the information condition and 19 percent in the no message condition. The difference between the theory-based and the information conditions was not significant. However, in the same program of research, another study (Murphy and Brubaker 1990) reported a large and significant difference between the theory-based and the information conditions:
Analysis of data collected at follow-up one month later indicated a significant relationship between exposure to the persuasive messages and self-reported TSE behavior (χ2 [DF=2] = 11.11, p < .004). Forty-two percent of participants exposed to the theory-based message reported performing TSE, compared to 23% of participants exposed to the informational message and 6% of subjects in the control condition. (p. 461)
The author and the special editor regret the original error.
